metadata.title: Microwave absorbing property enhancement of FeSiCr nanomaterials by regulating nanoparticle size

sections.text:

Journal of Alloys and Compounds

Microwave absorbing property enhancement of FeSiCr nanomaterials by regulating nanoparticle size
Lei Wang*, 1, Houdong Xiong 1, Sajjad Ur Rehman, Qiulan Tan, Yang Chen, Lili Zhang, Jinpin Yang, Fangzheng Wu, Minglong Zhong, Zhenchen Zhong**
Jiangxi Key Laboratory for Rare Earth Magnetic Materials and Devices/ Institute for Rare Earth Magnetic Materials and Devices (IREMMD), Jiangxi University of Science and Technology, Ganzhou, 341000, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 24 February 2019 Received in revised form 25 June 2019 Accepted 26 June 2019 Available online 27 June 2019
Keywords: Absorbing material FeSiCr nanomaterials Impedance matching Nanoparticle size
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: wanglei15526@163.com (L. W (Z. Zhong).
1 Lei Wang and Houdong Xiong contributed equall
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2019.06.327 0925-8388/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
FeSiCr nanoparticles were fabricated by plasma arc-discharging method. The particle size is controlled by regulating the ratio of Ar and H2. The proper particle size improves the microwave attenuation capability and optimizes the impedance matching of the FeSiCr nanoparticles. When the ratio of Ar:H2¼ 80:20, the calculated reflectivity of the FeSiCr nanoparticle reaches 50.7 dB at 17.3 GHz (d¼ 1.5mm). By regulating the proportion of heat source gas H2 and changing the coating thickness from 1.0 to 4.0mm, the effective absorbing bandwidth (<-10 dB) can be adjusted from 4.8 to 18 GHz. The excellent microwave absorbing performance indicates that the FeSiCr nanoparticles could be an attractive choice for microwave absorbing materials, and the method of regulating the proportion of heat source gas H2 is a feasible way to control the nanoparticle size.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The environmental problems caused by electromagnetic radiation have become serious issues with the rapid development of modern electronic technology [1,2]. Microwave absorbingmaterials have attracted great interest due to their applications in attenuation of electromagnetic pollution. These materials are also used in radar detection technology and stealth technology in the military field. Magnetic absorbing materials, specifically the Fe-based soft magnetic absorbing materials are investigated extensively [3e5].
Ferrites and ferromagnetic metal powders are themost reported soft magnetic absorbing materials [5e8]. Due to the higher permeability of ferromagnetic metals, the absorbing properties of low price Fe-based metal powders are reported widely [2e8]. The FeSi alloy powders are commonly used as soft magnetic materials. In order to improve themagnetic permeability of the FeSimaterials, a small amount of Al or Cr elements are doped to optimize the microstructure [9e11]. Therefore, the potential FeSiAl and FeSiCr
ang), zczhong2013@163.com
y to this work.
absorber with superior permeability have been paid extensive attention [7,8,12e20]. For further improving the absorbing properties of FeSi-based materials, researchers have tried various methods to modify the FeSiAl and FeSiCr materials, such as using ball-milling method to obtain the flaky FeSiAl [7,13,14] and FeSiCr [8,18,19] particles. Due to the low eddy current losses resulting from shape anisotropy, the flaky particles may have high resonance frequency above Snoek's limit [8]. Researchers also combine FeSiCr and FeSiAl materials with different forms of carbon materials such as graphite@FeSiAl [7], CNT (canbon nanotube)@FeSiAl [15e17], and surface carbon coating on FeSiAl and FeSiCr particles [17,21]. These studies have achieved some meaningful results.
However, the reported research results are more focused on micron-sized FeSi-based powders, and there are relatively few studies available on the nano-sized powders. In this paper, FeSiCr nanopowders with a particle size of less than 100 nm were fabricated and investigated. The particle size has been tailored by varying the proportion of heat source gas H2 during the plasma arcdischarging process. Controlling the particle size can make the magnetic properties better, while ensuring low eddy current losses, thereby achieving the purpose of increasing the magnetic permeability.
Fig. 2. TEM micrographs (a)e(c), and calculated nanoparticle size

sections.heading: 2. Experimental
sections.text:
The FeSiCr nanoparticles were prepared by evaporating the alloy in Ar and H2 atmosphere with plasma arc-discharging method. In a typical procedure, Fe, Si, Cr with purity higher than 99.99% were melted into FeSiCr alloy with a composition of Fe:Si:Cr¼ 90:7.9:2.1 (wt.%). The FeSiCr ingots were evaporated by plasma arcdischarging in a mixed atmosphere of Ar and H2. The Ar:H2 ratio was varied as 90:10, 80:20 and 70:30. The respective samples were marked as S1, S2 and S3. The plasma arc-discharging current of 60e80 A was maintained for 1 h to evaporate the ingot alloys sufficiently. The powder was put in passivation for 8 h in the mixed atmosphere of Ar and a small quantity of dry air.
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by using a D8-advance (Bruker/AXS, Germany) diffractometer with monochromatic Cu Ka radiation. Transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 20) was used to observe the nano structure and morphologies. The magnetic properties of the samples were obtained by applying physical property measurement system, (PPMS,
distribution maps (d)e(f) of (a) S1 (b) S2 and (c) S3 samples.
Quantum Design, USA). The FeSiCr nanoparticles were mixed with paraffin in mass ratio of 4:1. Coaxial rings of the mixtures were made with a thickness of 3.5mm, of which the inside and outside diameters were 3.04mm and 7.0mm, respectively. The vector network analyzer (Agilent PNAN5244A) was used to measure the complex permittivity and complex permeability in the frequency range of 2e18 GHz.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of the samples prepared in a mixed atmosphere of Ar and H2 are shown in Fig. 1. All the samples (S1, S2 and S3) depict a-Fe single phase with the characteristic peaks at 44.7 , 65.0 and 82.3 of 2q. The peaks are indexed as (110), (200) and (211) respectively by comparing with JCPDS card No. 06e0696. Considering the 2.1% of Cr in the samples, the detected single phase should be the (Fe∙Cr) solid solution phase [8]. According to some previous reports, a small amount of DO3 superlattice phase (2q at ~30 ) may appear in the FeSiCr alloy [19,20]. However, no significant characteristic peaks were observed in our samples, which may be due the low Si content.
The TEM micrographs of the as-prepared FeSiCr nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2 (a)-(c), the overall appearance of all the samples is spherical. It can be seen that the diameter of the nanoparticles becomes larger with the increase of H2 content. We calculated the nanoparticle size distribution in Fig. 2 (a)(c) with NanoMeasure software v1.2 (Fudan University, China), and the results are demonstrated in Fig. 2 (e)-(f). The calculated average diameters of S1, S2, and S3 samples are ~27 nm, ~51 nm, and ~75 nm, respectively. The average diameters of the nanoparticles increase due to the increase in the content of the heat source gas H2, which results higher temperature inside the chamber, benefiting the growth of crystalline grain.
The frequency dependence of complex permittivity (εr) and
Fig. 3. (a) Real part of complex permittivity (εʹ), (b) imaginary part of complex permittiv permeability (m") of samples S1, S2, and S3.
complex permeability (mr) of FeSiCr nanoparticles in the frequency range of 2e18 GHz are displayed in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3 (a) and (b), the εr increases with the increase of H2 proportion, especially the real part ε'. The reason is the same as discussed above: the higher proportion of heat source gas inside the chamber results in a higher temperature. High temperature benefits the growth of crystalline grain, which can enhance the conductivity of the samples. According to the free electron theory, high conductivity results in high permittivity [4]. The m' and m'' values of the three samples are shown in Fig. 3 (c) and (d). The vales of both m' and m'' increase by increasing the proportion of H2 from 10% to 20%. In contrast, the m' and m'' values decrease continuously with the proportion of H2 increases from 20% to 30%. The relative increase of S2 may be due to the higher temperature in the chamber, which benefits the crystallization of the sample. Furthermore, the higher temperature can decrease the defects and internal stresses of the sample, which is beneficial for the repair of permeability.
In order to find the reasons for the decrease of permeability of sample S3, we measured the room temperature hysteresis loops (M H) and plotted the m00(m0) 2f 1 curves of S1, S2, and S3 samples. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the saturation magnetization (Ms/emu g 1) increases with the proportion of H2 increases from 10% to 20%, leading to an increase in magnetic permeability. However, the Ms shows no significant change when the proportion of H2 increases from 20% to 30%, which is in contrast to the significant decline of mr. According to skin-effect criterion [22], the eddy current loss can be calculated from the values of m00(m0) 2f 1. It is reported that the values of m00(m0) 2f 1 remain constant with changing f when the magnetic loss solely results from eddy current loss effects [22]. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the values of m00(m0) 2f 1 remain nearly constant for sample S2 over ~10e~18 GHz and sample S3 over ~4e~15 GHz, indicating that magnetic loss mainly originates from the eddy currents in the corresponding band. The eddy current loss band of the S3 sample is wider than that of S2. Equation (1)
ity (ε"), (c) real part of complex permeability (mʹ) and (d) imaginary part of complex
expresses the average power loss versus the eddy current loss of sphere [23]:
Pe ¼ 15 p2f 2B2m r R2 (1)
Where Pe is average power loss, f is the frequency, Bm is the magnetic induction, r is the density, and R is the radius of the sphere, respectively. As can be observed in equation (1), the Pe is directly proportional to R2, so an increase in particle size leads to an increase in eddy current loss. Therefore, the increase in particle size from ~51 nm (sample S2) to ~75 nm (sample S3) leads to an increase in eddy current loss, resulting in the decrease in mr of the S3 sample [24]. The inset in Fig. 4 (a) shows the coercivity (Hc/kOe) of S1, S2, and S3 samples. The coercivity (Hc) increases with the increase of H2 content. Herzer et al. [25] reported that the larger the grain size, the greater the Hc when the grain size of soft magnetic material is less than ~100 nm which is confirmed by the observed increase in particle size from S1 to S3 as shown in Fig. 2.
According to transmission line theory, the reflection loss (RL/dB) of a microwave absorbing layer terminated by perfect conductor can be calculated from the complex permittivity and complex permeability by using the following equations [26]: Zin ¼ Z0 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi mr=εr p tanh jð2pfd=cÞ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffimrεrp (2)
RLðdBÞ¼ 20lgjðZin Z0Þ=ðZin þ Z0Þj (3)
where Zin and Z0 are the input impedance of the absorber and the intrinsic impedance of the free space respectively, εr and mr are the complex permittivity and permeability which can be obtained from Fig. 3, c is the velocity of light, f is the frequency of electromagnetic wave and d is the coating thickness. The calculated results are depicted in Fig. 5. Sample S2 is the best absorber among the three samples as demonstrated in Fig. 5 (a). The minimum calculated RL value of S2 reaches 21.8 dB at 13.7 GHz and the effective absorbing bandwidth (RL < 10 dB) is more than 8 GHz (d¼ 1.8mm). To reveal the influence of the different thicknesses and frequency on RL values, three dimension RL curve of S2 sample is shown in Fig. 5(b). The minimum calculated RL value of S2 sample reaches 50.7 dB at 17.3 GHz (d¼ 1.5mm). By changing the coating thickness from 1.0 to 4.0mm, the effective absorbing bandwidth of sample S2 ranges from 4.8 to 18 GHz. Table 1 presents the microwave absorption properties of other similar absorbing materials [7e9,13e16,18,19]. Our findings reveal that the FeSiCr nanoparticles can be an attractive candidate for microwave absorbing materials.
Furthermore, two important conditions must be satisfied to
achieve strong absorption andwide effective absorbing bandwidth: i) good microwave attenuation; and ii) outstanding impedance matching between microwave absorber and the free space. The dielectric loss factor (tan dE¼ ε"/ε0), and magnetic loss factor (tan dM¼ m"/m0) are applied to find the electromagnetic loss capacities. As shown in Fig. 6(a), dielectric loss factor of S1, S2 and S3 samples depicts no significant change as a whole. In contrast, the magnetic loss factor of S2 sample is clearly larger than that of the S1 and S3 samples as shown in Fig. 6(b). Such larger magnetic loss factor should be mainly due to the larger magnetic permeability. As discussed in Fig. 3, the larger magnetic permeability could be
attributed to the repair of magnetic properties and relatively low eddy current losses of S2 sample. Since the magnetic loss dominates, the total loss factor of S2 sample is larger than that of the other two samples as shown in Fig. 6(c).
The attenuation constant a is an important parameter for evaluating electromagnetic wave dissipation, according to the electromagnetic wave propagation theory, a can be expressed by equation (4):
a ¼ ffiffiffi 2 p pf
ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ðm"ε" m0ε0Þ þ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ðm"ε" m0ε0Þ2 þ ðm"ε" þ m0ε0Þ2 qr
c (4)
where f is the frequency of electromagnetic wave, c is the velocity of light. As shown in Fig. 7(a), the a value of the S2 sample is obviously the largest, which indicates the best microwave loss capability. The best impedance matching condition is achieved when the calculated value of jZin/Z0j is equal to 1 [4]. It is obvious, as shown in Fig. 7(b), that the S2 sample displays the best impedance matching
values, which also confirms the optimal absorbing properties.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, the FeSiCr nanoparticles were successfully synthesizedwith plasma arc-dischargingmethod. The particle sizewas controlled by regulating the ratio of Ar and H2. The particle size of FeSiCr nanoparticles can be effectively regulated by changing the proportion of heat source H2. The FeSiCr nanoparticles showed the best absorbing properties when the ratio of Ar:H2¼ 80:20. The calculated reflectivity of the obtained FeSiCr nanoparticle reached 50.7 dB at 17.3 GHz (d¼ 1.5mm). The excellent microwave absorbing properties can be attributed to the enhanced microwave attenuation capability and the optimized impedance matching. We hope this method could be applied to various other systems and it can become an important method to regulate the size of nanoparticles. Consequently, the FeSiCr nanoparticles with suitable particle size would be an attractive candidate for microwave absorbing materials.

metadata.abstractText: FeSiCr nanoparticles were fabricated by plasma arc-discharging method. The particle size is controlled by regulating the ratio of Ar and H2. The proper particle size improves the microwave attenuation capability and optimizes the impedance matching of the FeSiCr nanoparticles. When the ratio of Ar:H21⁄4 80:20, the calculated reflectivity of the FeSiCr nanoparticle reaches 50.7 dB at 17.3 GHz (d1⁄4 1.5mm). By regulating the proportion of heat source gas H2 and changing the coating thickness from 1.0 to 4.0mm, the effective absorbing bandwidth (<-10 dB) can be adjusted from 4.8 to 18 GHz. The excellent microwave absorbing performance indicates that the FeSiCr nanoparticles could be an attractive choice for microwave absorbing materials, and the method of regulating the proportion of heat source gas H2 is a feasible way to control the nanoparticle size. © 2019 Elsevier B.V.
